Determinants!
Crucial to eigenvalues/vectors

Can we find some test $op(A)$ that is 1 when invertible, 0 when singular?
Eventually, $\det(A) = 0 \implies A$ singular

$\det(A) = \sum_\sigma {sign(\sigma)\prod_i{a_{i\sigma(i)}}}$

$\det(A) = \det(A^T)$
$\det(I) = 1$
$\det(U) = $ product of diagonal
$\det(L) = $ product of diagonal
Scaling a row scales the determinant
(Row operations preserve determinant; also preserve row space!)
(Swapping a row negates the determinant)

Cofactor expansion
$\matrixstart 1 & 2 \\ 3 & 1 \matrixend$, $\det = 1 \cdot 1 - 2 \cdot 3$
Especially useful for $\mathbb{R}^{3 \times 3}$
Remember that the sign alternates!

Big Theorem:
$\det(AB) = \det(A)\det(B)$
This tells us that $A$ and $B$ are invertible $\iff$ $AB$ is invertible
